Authors:
Jeffrey Hunter Skevington, Jamie Morris-Pocock, James
Pawlicki, Scott Kelso, Kevin Kerr, Marcie Jacklin
Title:
Pinpointing the origin of the Great LakesÂ’ first Brown Booby
(Aves: Sula leucogaster)
Keywords:
distribution, vagrant, mtDNA, new record, Ontario, DNA
extraction, faeces, faecal sample, DNA identification
Abstract:
The first Brown Booby recorded in the Great Lakes basin
was discovered on Lake Erie near the source of the Niagara River on the
7th of October 2013 by James Pawlicki. Morphological evidence suggested
that this bird was an adult female of the nominate Atlantic subspecies.
We obtained genomic DNA from faeces left by the bird. Mitochondrial DNA
from the control region (CR2) was sequenced and compared to extensive
Brown Booby CR2 data available in GenBank, and corroborated the
morphological hypothesis. This is the first time that a vagrant bird has
been identified using DNA extracted from faeces.
